tickets.summary: init edit fields display excess characters
tickets.description:
Build: r480
Operating System: Linux

What Happened: Edit Fields in init are not properly cleaning out old field information when the previous data was longer than the new data.  The new data works correctly, it appears to only be a display issue (ie, the display appears to be based on a fixed field size rather than where the string actually ends).

What was expected:  When a field is edited, the fixed field excess should be zeroed out and/or the display should use the string itself and not the field size.

Can you provide a screenshot?

From the "general system config" screen

Old system name entry:
System name      : The Beagle, Part 2

New system name entry after editing: (should be just "test name")
System name      : test namee, Part 2

posts.text: what do you mean, the characters after the cursor is not removed when changing fields.  you have to delete them if you don't want them.
posts.author: rushfan
posts.subject: #77 init edit fields display excess characters

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: David Rock
posts.author: rushfan
posts.subject: #77 init edit fields display excess characters

posts.text:
OK, so that's expected behavior; but that's not **intuitive** behavior.  It's unusual for an edit field to retain text and overwrite from the beginning.  Most interfaces would completely replace the field with the new text.  The current behavior looks more like a display bug than expected behavior and is confusing.

I did verify that it uses the whole field, though; not just the new text like I originally thought.
posts.author: rockdw
posts.subject: #77 init edit fields display excess characters

posts.text: As discussed on IRC I think that this matches how DOS apps used to do it and changing that would be surprising.  That said init can improve a lot and let's see what we can do to make line editing better.  I'll keep looking around for some libraries that may help

tickets.description:
In "Language Configuration" of the program "init" I have the following:
"
Language name  : English░░░░░░░░░░░░                                         OVR
Data Directory : /home/wwiv/menus/en/

posts.text:
A couple questions:
1. How did you populate the directory structure?  Did you extract a WWIV 4.30, or use the WWIV 5.00 zip file?
2. Are you working off of the Installing WWIV on Linux information?
3. Is the actual message "\*MENU\* : Unable to open Menu", or something else?

There are a few potential reasons:
1. Your pathing is wrong - The path for both, based on your info, should probably be /home/wwiv/gfiles/
2. Your path is missing - Init on linux does not extract the en-menus.zip file.  You have to do that yourself.
3. Your filename case is wrong - There's a known issue with a lot of files where the code expects UPPER.lower, but you probably have lower.lower filenames

posts.subject: #78 Language Configuration

posts.text: Ok. I think I fixed it. I ln -s'd the files in the menu directory to upper.lower format. Thanks for the tip.
posts.author: ignatius33
posts.subject: #78 Language Configuration

posts.text:
ok, the bbs/admin directory doesn't have everything you need.  It's missing the gfiles contents.  You will be better off expanding the build zip file from http://build.wwiv.us/job/WWIV/186/artifact/archives/wwiv-build-484-186.zip
in your base WWIV directory, then extracting the en-menus.zip in your /home/wwiv/gfiles directory.  That will get you the right files in the right place.  You still need the linux compiled binaries; the contents of the build zip file are the Windows binaries.  Expanding the zip file will not overwrite your existing linux binaries.

You will still need to address the Upper.lower name issue.  There's a pretty long list of broken filenames at the moment, but changing /home/wwiv/gfiles/menus/wwiv/xfer.* to XFER.lower (eg, xfer.mnu to XFER.mnu) should get you your Transfer menu.  You can either link the file (soft or hard), or flat out change the name.  This is an area that still has a lot of work to be done.

Another place that needs symlinking is in /home/wwiv/gfiles.  all the *.msg files need to be changed (eg, mbslash.msg to MBSLASH.MSG)

tickets.summary: nodemgr isn't spawning properly via xinetd
tickets.description:
When I use xinetd to spawn nodemgr, it isn't spawning the bbs as expected.

What I expect to see is:
wwiv@wdfs ~ $ ./nodemgr
WWIV 5.0 UNIX Node Manager Bootstrap.
Please wait while node data is parsed.
Found 1/4 Nodes in use.
Invoking WWIV with cmd line:
./wwiv /N2 /I2

WWIV v5.00/Linux  (Development)
Copyright (c) 1998-2014 WWIV Software Services.
All Rights Reserved.
This is GFILES\WELCOME.MSG.
Edit to suit your needs.

Enter number or name or 'NEW'
NN:

----------------------
What I actually get is:
damocles:~ drock$ telnet wdfs
Trying 192.168.1.10...
Connected to wdfs.graniteweb.com.
Escape character is '^]'.

WWIV v5.00/Linux  (Development)
Copyright (c) 1998-2014 WWIV Software Services.
All Rights Reserved.
^[[47;1RThis is GFILES\WELCOME.MSG.
Edit to suit your needs.

Enter number or name or 'NEW'
NN: 1
1
PW:
PH: ###-###-


ILLEGAL LOGON


Enter number or name or 'NEW'
NN:

Unknown user.

Enter number or name or 'NEW'
NN:


Unknown user.
Too many logon attempts!!

Would you like to leave Feedback to GranitePenguin? No
WWIV Bulletin Board System v5.00 (Development) exiting at error level 0
-----------------

As you can see, The nodemgr bootstrap info doesn't seem to be getting processed properly when started via xinetd:

WWIV 5.0 UNIX Node Manager Bootstrap.
Please wait while node data is parsed.
Found 1/4 Nodes in use.
Invoking WWIV with cmd line:
./wwiv /N2 /I2

This may be an issue with pathing (xinetd has no file path, so I think things are out of whack for nodemgr).  One possible solution would be to add a commandline argument to nodemgr so that you can define the directory to spawn the bbs binary from.

A quick primer on xinetd.  You can define services to run that are managed by xinetd, so the binary isn't running all the time.  A sample config file for wwiv is:
service wwiv
{
        type            = UNLISTED
        port            = 23
        socket_type     = stream
        wait            = no
        user            = wwiv
        server          = /bbs/wwiv/nodemgr
        server_args     = 
        log_on_failure += USERID
        disable         = no
}
so when you hit the defined port, xinetd spawns the listed server.

I tried using a shell script instead and changing the directory with that, but the results were the same.  It just feels like processes are forking out of order when run this way.  It may just be something weird with xinetd, I don't know.  I think Xenos is using the older inetd config to run his.

Another option would be to have nodemgr be its own proper service that listens on the port.  That would potentially be a place to recreate the WFC screen, but it would also probably require you to use screen to leave the process running... blech.

posts.text: From what I can tell so far, it looks like xinetd (at least the way I'm using it)  is having some issues with the ESC codes and character input. Generally speaking, xinetd is "better" than inetd (security, etc), but if it doesn't present the right env, it won't be much use.
posts.author: rockdw
posts.subject: #66 nodemgr isn't spawning properly via xinetd

posts.text:
Ok, I've sorted out what's happening here.  I just had to mimic what inetd does and use in.telnetd to spawn the nodemanager instead of calling it directly.  because of pathing weirdness, I wrapped it up in a shell script to set everything.

This can be closed for now.  It won't matter until we change the nodemanager to be more of a standalone service, which may not be worth the effort.
posts.author: rockdw
posts.subject: #66 nodemgr isn't spawning properly via xinetd

posts.text:
So the actual difference is using in.telnetd.  All you need are two things:
1. a stub shell script that sets your path (I called it in.nodemgr). Make sure you chmod +x it.

~~~~~
#!/bin/bash 
#
# in.nodemgr
#
# This is a stub script to set the path and call nodemgr
# Obviously, set the path to whatever you are using

cd /bbs/wwiv
./nodemgr
~~~~~

2. an entry in /etc/xinetd.d/
I named mine /etc/xinetd.d/wwiv


----
service wwiv
{
        type            = UNLISTED
        port            = 23
        socket_type     = stream
        wait            = no
        user            = wwiv
        server          = /usr/sbin/in.telnetd
        server_args     = -L /bbs/wwiv/in.nodemgr
        log_on_failure += USERID
        disable         = no
}

----

Then restart your xinetd service.  You should see something like this in /var/log/messages

May 14 15:07:14 wdfs xinetd[7203]: xinetd Version 2.3.15 started with libwrap loadavg options compiled in.
May 14 15:07:14 wdfs xinetd[7203]: Started working: 1 available service


----
For cleanup of stale processes, you can cron something like the following:

~~~~~
#!/bin/bash
#
# lists all wwiv nodes and kills anything that doesn't have 
# a pty.  For example, process 7414 below is a dead instance:
#
# 7422 pts/6    ./wwiv /N2 /I2
# 7414 ?        ./wwiv /N1 /I1
#

for i in `ps -C wwiv -o pid=,tt=,cmd= | awk '{if ($2=="?") print $1}'`
do
        kill $i
done
~~~~~

tickets.summary: NETXX processing on logout loops forever
tickets.description:
Build: r443

Operating System: Linux (Gentoo)

What Happened: When logging off, the system tried to process outgoing netmail, but fails while looking for a network1 shell script.  it just goes into an infinite loop of:

/bin/sh: network1: command not found
/bin/sh: network1: command not found
/bin/sh: network1: command not found
/bin/sh: network1: command not found
/bin/sh: network1: command not found

I had to find the process with ps and kill it manually.

What was expected: I expected one of two things:
1. A graceful handling of the missing shell script (ie, fail and exit; not loop)
2. The proper script gets run.

Can you provide a screenshot?  Not applicable; the text above is all that you see (ie, there's not graphical component to show).

I haven't had a chance to trace where this gets called yet.  I thought it might be in bbs/platform/unix/exec.cpp (UnixSpawn), but when I tried to use gdb, it just exited quietly (ie, no looping).

posts.text: You need a script named network1 which calls dosemu -dumb -E network1.bat, which will process the outbound pXX-NN.net files. The loop occurs because the pXX-NN.net still exists. But yes, the BBS should handle the executable not being available and instead report an error.
posts.author: xenos
posts.subject: #71 NETXX processing on logout loops forever

posts.text:
What should _actually_ happen is the whole mechanism for running stuff during a logout should be moved to a separate service. It's sloppy that a user has to see backend transactional stuff when they log out at all; especially if they use /O

as far as the script is concerned; it isn't clear what is trying to run it in the first place.  The location of the script (or it's contents) is also vague.  Is this something that gets used on the Windows side, too?
posts.author: rockdw
posts.subject: #71 NETXX processing on logout loops forever

posts.text: So netXX stuff shouldn't be called from the BBS itself. It should be handled outside the BBS main process. I'll review the code for other occurences of this. Our architecture is changing from the single task/process model of the original WWIV on DOS, so the code should also reflect this.
posts.author: xenos
posts.subject: #71 NETXX processing on logout loops forever

posts.text:
the calling of network1/2 on logoff is a critical part of the logoff procedure, it is used to rename the temporary network packet from p0-??.net files to s???.net/z???.net.  The BBS itself does not know or need to know how to process this rename/append operation.

This execution should be instead adjusted to only execute the process *IF* the file exists.
posts.author: atani
posts.subject: #71 NETXX processing on logout loops forever

posts.text:
I do not disagree here.  On a Linux system it should be done in a silent mode in a separate background service that is not part of the logout procedure.  One option for doing this is disable the network functionality on all nodes (via wwiv.ini) and then have a crontab as:
*/5 * * * * check_net.sh

In check_net.sh it would look for the p0-??.net file(s) and process them accordingly.

tickets.description: Under Linux, the function printfile only works if given the filename that needs displayed, including extension. It does not properly build the filename.ext based on the user's ANSI settings, and will only attempt to display the exact filename that is passed to it.

posts.author: rushfan

posts.text: Yes. I have tried with both upper and lower. I thought maybe it just wasn't falling back to .msg if .ans doesn't exist, but that is not the case. posts.author: wintermute740

posts.text: 'mute, which filename are you seeing the bug in? so we can reproduce the bug and see how we might fix it. i mean, how do we make the bug appear?
posts.author: xenos
posts.subject: #57 function printfile()

posts.text:
Pretty much any filename with the macro of <FILENAME>_NOEXT defined, since printfile is typically called with those macros. For example, chat, editor, email, feedback, logoff, logon, lpfreq, lpsysop, mbmain, menuwel, mmail, newuser, rs-email, sbmain, sonline, srestrict, suedit, system, tarchive, and tbatch. I apologize if I missed any ;) The only way I can get them to display on my system is if I create the filename without the extension at all. (Note, welcome isn't included in this because printfile is called via macros which include the extension .msg or .ans, based on ansi detection and not the user's ansi settings.)

I'm a little rusty in C++, so I haven't tracked the bug down yet. Renaming my files was far easier ;)

posts.text:
This appears to be related to incorrect parsing/handling of wwiv.ini.

When I added the new TEMP_DIRECTORY variables, things broke

~~~~~
;=============================================================================
;                        TEMPORARY DIRECTORY SETTING
;=============================================================================
NUM_INSTANCES        = 4
TEMP_DIRECTORY       = temp%n
BATCH_DIRECTORY      = batch%n
~~~~~


The issue is in the placement of those variables.  When I added them, I put them in the same place they exist in the wwivini.500 sample file (right above the INSTANCE SPECIFIC OPTIONS).  Based on how ini file formatting works, this technically puts them in the [CTYPES] section of the ini file.  If I move them _above_ the [CTYPES] section heading (ie, under the [WWIV] heading), the segfault does not occur.

So, instead of (this breaks):

~~~~~
[WWIV]
[CTYPES]
NUM_INSTANCES        = 4
TEMP_DIRECTORY       = temp%n
BATCH_DIRECTORY      = batch%n
[WWIV-1]
[WWIV-2]
~~~~~

do (this works):

~~~~~
[WWIV]
NUM_INSTANCES        = 4
TEMP_DIRECTORY       = temp%n
BATCH_DIRECTORY      = batch%n
[CTYPES]
[WWIV-1]
[WWIV-2]
~~~~~

tickets.description:
Build:r659
Operating System:linux

What Happened: while using telnetd, if you ^] the telnet server will break out and drop to the telnet> prompt. If you do this while using a FSED, it stops the timer and never reclaims the node.

What was expected: If the telnet daemon loses connectivity, the child process should be killed.  This goes back to the old cleanup issue... nodemgr (or something) needs to know what the parent telnetd processid is, monitor when it goes away and send sighups to the child pids. 

It's also worth noting that this particular example involves ^] being intercepted by telnetd.  If nodemgr were managing the connection port directly, that wouldn't be an issue, but introduces some other potential headaches (i.e., why reinvent the wheel if you don't have to).

posts.author: rockdw
posts.subject: #162 Menu editor does not display names of menus

posts.text:
It is finding the right path

~~~~~
(gdb) next
885	  bout.nl();
(gdb) print path
$4 = "/bbs/wwiv/gfiles/menus/wwiv/*.mnu"
~~~~~


and it's finding the files, but when it calls fnd.IsFile(), it's returning false so it isn't printing.  Looking at WFindFile::IsFile()

~~~~~
bool WFindFile::IsFile() {
  if (nCurrentEntry > nMatches) {
    return false;
  }

  return (nFileType & DT_BLK);
}
~~~~~

It's not doing what it's supposed to, since nCurrentEntry is less than nMatches (see below)

~~~~~
(gdb) next
892	    if (fnd.IsFile()) {
(gdb)
896	    bFound = fnd.next();
(gdb) print fnd
$8 = {_vptr.WFindFile = 0x81b1540 <vtable for WFindFile+8>,
  filename_ = "XFER.mnu", filespec_ = "????????.mnu", lFileSize = 20,
  lTypeMask = 0, nFileType = 8 '\b', bIsOpen = false, entries = 0x8212c80,
  nMatches = 5, nCurrentEntry = 1}
~~~~~

It is correctly skipping to 

return (nFileType & DT_BLK); 

but what is the value being returned?

~~~~~
(gdb) print nCurrentEntry
$1 = 1
(gdb) print nMatches
$2 = 5
(gdb) next
156	  return (nFileType & DT_BLK);
(gdb) print nFileType
$3 = 8 '\b'
(gdb) print DT_BLK
$4 = DT_BLK
~~~~~

because whatever '\\b' & DT_BLK is, it's evaluating to false.
